newsitem.title: SWITZERLAND: Never a dull moment as Swiss army knife turns 100.
newsitem.headline: Never a dull moment as Swiss army knife turns 100.

text.p: The Swiss army knife, the all-purpose implement favoured by presidents, polar explorers, astronauts and millions of ordinary people reluctant to carry a tool box around with them, turned 100 on Thursday.

From humble beginnings as a pocket knife with six fold-out blades and tools, the implement has spawned dozens of ever more complex variations featuring gizmos designed to unclog car windscreen washer jets or remove a fish's scales.
Manufacturer Victorinox laconically calls the penknife, patented by cutlery maker Carl Elsener on June 12, 1897, a "useful pocket tool", but the stories of its exploits are legion.
Last May, Hansjoerg Schwob, a Swiss policeman, was trapped in an attic of a customs office in Basle as he was looking for a meeting on a Friday afternoon when a door blew shut behind him.
"I cried out, yelled, pounded and knocked, but it was all no use," he said.
Luckily, his "City Knife" model was equipped with a screwdriver on the end of a fruit-peeler which quickly dismantled the lock.
In another incident, a Swiss army knife was successfully used as a scalpel for an emergency tracheotomy on a child choking on a hard candy on a flight from Bombay to Bangalore.
American astronauts on the space shuttle use the knives.
During an expedition to the North Pole in 1976/77, explorer Charles Burton found his knife invaluable for more than just de-icing sleigh runners and opening tins.

"When one of our team broke through the ice, we were able to cut off his clothes with the knife," he wrote in an account of the expedition. If his clothes, rapidly freezing at minus 37 Celsius, had not been cut off, he would probably have died rapidly.
Some 34,000 Swiss army knives leave the Victorinox factory in Ibach in central Switzerland daily. Its 950 staff make it the biggest employer in the regional canton of Schywz.
The company, named after Elsener's mother Victoria and "Inox", a designation for stainless steel, is now run by the founder's grandson, Carl Elsener III, aged 75.
Elsener's classic six-tool red knife, emblazoned with the Swiss cross trademark, sports a large and a small blade, a can opener, a bottle opener, a corkscrew, and an awl with a hole for sewing.
"Our knives are not intended as weapons," said Hans Schorno, spokesman for Victorinox.

Other models feature scissors, magnifying glasses, saws, rulers, pliers or fish-scaling implements, right up to the "Swiss Champ", the most luxurious of around 100 models, which has 33 blades and tools.
Over 450 steps are required in its manufacture. It weighs 185 grams and was included in the New York Museum of Modern Art's collection of excellence in design.
A commemorative centenary edition is also being produced.
Victorinox says every U.S. president since Lyndon Johnson has presented guests to the White House with its knives, making use of perhaps their most appreciated function of all, as a souvenir.
